oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Proclamation by Governor Newton Cannon Calling for 2500 Volunteers from Tennessee to Serve in Creek Country
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Proclamation issued by Governor Newton Cannon requesting 2500 volunteers from Tennessee to answer President Andrew Jackson's call for a war on the Creek Indians. It spells out the reasons for a call to arms and explains how volunteers are to be organized and outfitted.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides
Broadsides; Creek War, 1836; Creek Indians; Cannon, Newton, 1781-1841; Jackson, Andrew, 1767-1845
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Creek Indian tribes were disbanded and forced to come under Alabama law in 1832. When settlers began to infringe on Creek land, the Creek Indians revolted. Their insurrection was forcibly put down by troops under Gen. Winfield Scott and was the reason for the tribe's removal to Indian Territories west of the Mississippi.
